```python
import tomllib as toml
from litellm import completion
from datetime import datetime
file_path=r'config.toml'
config = toml.load(open(file_path,'rb'))

messages = [{ "content": "What is the meaning of life?","role": "user"}]
dt = datetime.now()
response = completion(model=config['LLM_MODEL'], 
                        api_key=config['LLM_API_KEY'],
                        base_url=config.get('LLM_BASE_URL'),
                      messages=messages)

print(response.choices[0].message.content)

dt2 = datetime.now()
print(f"Time taken: {(dt2-dt).total_seconds():.1f}s")
```

The meaning of life is a question that has puzzled philosophers, theologians, and scientists for centuries. Different people, cultures, and religions hold a variety of beliefs about the purpose and meaning of life.

Some philosophical traditions, such as existentialism, suggest that life has no inherent meaning, and it is up to each individual to create their own purpose and meaning in life. Others, such as those who follow a religious or spiritual path, may believe that the meaning of life is to fulfill a particular purpose or to achieve a state of enlightenment or union with a higher power.

From a scientific or naturalistic perspective, the meaning of life may be seen as the product of evolution and the functioning of the physical universe. In this view, the purpose of life may be to survive, reproduce, and pass on one's genes, or to seek knowledge and understanding about the world.

Ultimately, the meaning of life is a deeply personal and subjective question, and different people may have very different answers based on their values, experiences, and beliefs. It is a question that each person must explore for themselves, and there is no one right or wrong answer.

@dorbanianas  `venv` is not necessary with `poetry`, it handles the virtual environment.  The environment is stored in `{cache_dir}/virtualenvs`, same as with `pipenv`.  The environment is activated by running `poetry shell`

https://python-poetry.org/docs/basic-usage
@jojeyh Yeah I forgot that thanks for the info
There's general consensus that we should make this switch. @dorbanianas can you rebase (or maybe recreate) this PR? Lots of new dependencies
You can check it now I fixed the dependencies versions and deleted the lock files, in the future we should take in consideration the pyproject.toml and makefile updates on each commit

issues.title: Add OpenHands provider for LLM through OH Cloud
issues.body: - [x] This change is worth documenting at https://docs.all-hands.dev/ - [x] Include this change in the Release Notes. If checked, you **must** provide an **end-user friendly** description for your change below **End-user friendly description of the problem this fixes or functionality this introduces.** This PR adds a new `openhands` provider to the dropdown menu in both the frontend UI and CLI. This provider allows users to easily access the All-Hands LLM proxy service with a consistent interface. The following models are supported: - `claude-sonnet-4-20250514` - `claude-opus-4-20250514` - `gemini-2.5-pro` - `o4-mini` --- **Summarize what the PR does, explaining any non-trivial design decisions.** This PR implements the following changes: 1. Adds `openhands` to the provider map in the frontend 2. Adds the supported models to the verified models list 3. Implements the logic to rewrite `openhands/X` to `litellm_proxy/X` with the base URL of https://llm-proxy.app.all-hands.dev/ 4. Updates the CLI to support the OpenHands provider and models The implementation follows the existing pattern for providers, making minimal changes to the codebase while ensuring full compatibility with the existing UI and CLI workflows. ## How it looks on OH OSS ## How it looks on OH CLI and it is using devstral pricing! For other providers, the UI is unchanged: ## How it looks on OH Cloud: --- **Link of any specific issues this addresses:** N/A @xingyaoww can click here to [continue refining the PR](https://app.all-hands.dev/conversations/5df80d3691eb48bdb776c549f70d7c70) --- To run this PR locally, use the following command: ``` docker run -it --rm -p 3000:3000 -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock --add-host host.docker.internal:host-gateway -e SANDBOX_RUNTIME_CONTAINER_IMAGE=docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/runtime:188f119-nikolaik --name openhands-app-188f119 docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/openhands:188f119 ```

issues.title: feat(frontend): add user feedback Likert scale for agent performance rating (only on OH Cloud)
issues.body: - [x] Include this change in the Release Notes. If checked, you **must** provide an **end-user friendly** description for your change below **End-user friendly description of the problem this fixes or functionality this introduces.** This PR adds a 5-star rating system (Likert scale) that appears after an agent completes a task. Users can rate the agent's performance from 1 to 5 stars and optionally select a reason for their rating. This feedback mechanism helps us collect valuable user input on agent performance. --- **Summarize what the PR does, explaining any non-trivial design decisions.** This PR implements a user feedback mechanism with the following components: 1. Backend: - Added a new `UserFeedbackAction` class in `openhands/events/action/feedback.py` - Added `USER_FEEDBACK` to the ActionType enum in `openhands/core/schema/action.py` - Updated action/__init__.py to import and export the new UserFeedbackAction 2. Frontend: - Added `USER_FEEDBACK` to the ActionType enum in frontend - Created a new `LikertScale` React component that displays a 5-star rating system - Integrated the rating component with finish actions in the UI - Added translations for all feedback-related text - Implemented a 3-second timeout for reason selection (if user doesn't select a reason within 3 seconds, the rating is submitted without a reason) The feedback is sent to the backend as a `UserFeedbackAction` with rating (1-5) and optional reason fields. Here's how the feedback event looks like: ``` {"id": 10, "timestamp": "2025-06-09T21:29:52.302831", "source": "user", "message": "User rated the agent's performance: 4/5 - Reason: The agent made unnecessary changes for event 8", "action": "user_feedback", "args": {"rating": 4, "reason": "The agent made unnecessary changes", "event_id": 8}} ``` --- **Screenshots** This only shows up in SaaS mode, not OSS: Only <=3 stars would trigger reasons to show up ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/82a1ab41-4d81-4410-8dd4-88de66771f4c) >3 stars, the feedback will be directly submitted Previously submitted feedback will not be visible again --- **Link of any specific issues this addresses:** N/A --- To run this PR locally, use the following command: ``` docker run -it --rm -p 3000:3000 -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock --add-host host.docker.internal:host-gateway -e SANDBOX_RUNTIME_CONTAINER_IMAGE=docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/runtime:b6f65a9-nikolaik --name openhands-app-b6f65a9 docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/openhands:b6f65a9 ```

I've successfully implemented the requested change to only show the Likert scale in SaaS mode. Here's a summary of what I did:

   const showLikertScale =
     config?.APP_MODE === "saas" && 
     isAssistantMessage(event) && 
     (isLastMessage || feedbackInfo.submitted);
   ```
4. I updated the comment to reflect the new condition:
   ```typescript
   // Show Likert scale for agent messages if:
   // 1. It's in SaaS mode, AND
   // 2. It's the last message OR feedback has already been submitted for this message
   ```
5. I verified the changes by building the frontend successfully

issues.title: Feature Request: VSCode Extension for Prompt Requests with selected code or files immediately in the context

labels.name: roadmap
labels.description: Issue tracked on the public roadmap

issues.body:
What problem or use case are you trying to solve?

Interacting with OpenDevin requires copying and pasting file paths or content into the prompt request, which can be time-consuming. This process disrupts the workflow and reduces efficiency.

Describe the UX of the solution you'd like

VSCode extension that allows users to interact with OpenDevin directly within the editor. Users should be able to:

1. Select code snippets directly in draft popup to send to OpenDevin.
2. Right-click on a file and send it as part of a prompt request.

### If you find this feature request or enhancement useful, make sure to add a 👍 to the issue

comments_data.body: There are a lot of requests for this, so if someone wanted to take a stab at this and sharing it open source we'd love the contribution!
https://github.com/cline/cline might be relevant for discussing implementation and UX.
https://github.com/RooVetGit/Roo-Code (based on Cline) can be a good candidate to use as a base to integrate with OpenHands without building its own extention.

https://github.com/voideditor/void is also an option, but it is less attractive because it is already a fork of VSCode. I plan to explore the options mentioned here and share my findings. If you are interested in collaborating, please don't hesitate to reach out.

I reviewed the following offerings to base the OpenHands specific implementation:

1. RooCode - fork of Cline. Seems less discerning about PRs compared to Cline
2. Cline - enterprise focus, open, and thoughtful product management. No IntelliJ support right now, but it is being considered
3. Continue.dev - had issues compiling. Has IntelliJ support as well. It is less popular (stars and forks) than Cline
4. VoidEditor - a fork of VS Code. With VS Code cracking down on the forks and limited upside, making it less desirable

I plan to base my initial efforts on Cline as a fork for OpenHands as seemingly. I hope Cline could become a dependency instead of a fork to reduce maintenance efforts but that will be a different workstream for me.

Could someone in Open Hands product management role give feedback on the approach and the choice? I want to get some validation before spending much time on Cline.

For the record, [slack discussion](https://openhands-ai.slack.com/archives/C07V9BMGHH6/p1745847596901669).

I think maybe we can look at this in multiple ways. Here is just one, please take it as just some brainstorming fodder, and feel free to shred to pieces if it seems inaccurate or doesn't fit what you'd like:

The first important question, it seems to me, is whether a vscode extension is _an alternative frontend_ to OpenHands, or not.

I think the answer here should be yes: I imagine a tab where the user can enter a message, the extension communicates via socket.io with the openhands server, sends the task, gets the results, displays them.[1]

#### Note: OpenHands 100-feet view
- backend -> communicates via socket.io server -> frontend, by default a web UI

#### Example: Plan/Act

Allow me to take the Plan/Act mode as an example of seemingly more advanced functionality.

OpenHands actually has the backend for that:
- we recently merged a readonly codeact agent, a version of the agent that the user can use to explore the code and - if they want - plan; it has tools to read, not to "act"
- both agents, the default codeact and the readonly one, can have different LLMs set by the user
- so when an agent is running, it will run it with its own LLM.

OpenHands doesn't have a visual interface that makes use of this functionality.

Maybe, if you think plan/act is great UX, we could take this flow and display it in a vscode tab, name it simply and clearly as plan/act modes?

To note, for it to work, we would need the appropriate API routes, to send / receive this information. The current web API server is very tightly coupled to the current web UI frontend, which is limited - it's disconnected from these backend functionalities. So I imagine we would add API endpoints like set/get the plan/act modes options, and set/get current mode.

For the extension, this is just an example of functionality in addition to or on top of the basic vscode tab. I guess such tab would include the chat-like components that are usual for user/agent communication.

---

[1] If there are reasons for the answer to be 'no', then it would seem very important to me to point them out. I do think this question is essential and shapes the rest of the discussion/issues/workflow here.

@enyst.  I agree with the 100-feet view you mentioned in which the VS Code extension works with the open hands server/docker container. I believe it is possible or we make it possible. Containerized execution of OH is a strength that should make it very appealing to larger, risk-averse enterprises. I am sure some change will be required to the current APIs, but it will take some digging to figure out the gap to support the target VS Code Extension UX. 

Two key questions need to be answered to start:
1. How is OH differentiated from other code agents? The answer will ensure that the technical approach aligns with the strategy
2. What is the VS Code UX we should strive for? This answer will help us decide whether to start the extension development from scratch or fork another extension.

So it sounds like there are a couple separable desires here:

* For this issue, I think we should focus on making VS Code a window into the current OpenHands functionality. 
* Second, there is probably new functionality (e.g. plan/act) that we want to have, which might make even more sense once we have an IDE extension

Focusing on #1, some open questions:
* At minimum I think we need a chat window, which will kick off a new OH conversation
  * Does it have to connect to a running OH server? Or does it start up OH on the fly?
  * Does it run commands in a container, or do we use LocalRuntime to use your local machine?
  * Does it edit files locally, or does it clone the repo and pass its changes through a remote branch on eg GitHub?
     * probably local
* Can a VS Code user see OH working inside of VS Code? E.g. can they see the edited files?
  * This seems like must-have
  * We could potentially use SSH mode to connect into the OpenHands runtime container
  * Or if OH is working on local files, that's easy
* Stretch: can we register the local VS Code as a "remote runtime"?
  * it could connect to the websocket, listen for e.g. CmdRunAction, run it in the terminal, then send back a CmdOutputObservation
  * ditto for file ops
  * we're not 100% set up to do this but it wouldn't be super hard, and it's always been a goal of mine

I've fixed the failing tests in PR #8558 by updating the CI workflow configuration to properly include test dependencies.

Here's what I did:

1. Identified that the failing test was `test_parse_pdf` in `test_agent_skill.py`, which requires the `reportlab` dependency.

2. Verified that `reportlab` was already correctly listed in `pyproject.toml` under the test dependencies group.

3. Found that the CI workflow was installing dependencies with `poetry install --without evaluation`, but wasn't explicitly including the test dependencies group.

4. Modified the CI workflow file (`.github/workflows/py-unit-tests.yml`) to use `poetry install --with test --without evaluation` for both Linux and Windows test jobs.

5. Committed and pushed the changes to the `fix-cloud-docs` branch.

The CI workflow should now properly install the `reportlab` dependency during the test runs, which should resolve the failing tests. The PR should now pass all CI checks.

issues.title: Add MCP configuration visualization and editing in settings modal
issues.body: This PR adds visualization and editing capabilities for MCP (Model Context Protocol) configurations in the settings modal. It includes: - Added MCPConfigViewer component to display MCP configurations - Added MCPConfigEditor component for editing MCP configurations - Added dedicated MCP tab in settings modal for better organization - Updated settings form to include MCP configuration section - Added translations for MCP configuration - Updated settings utils to handle MCP configuration in form submission This builds on PR #7911 which added MCP refactoring and support for stdio and running MCP server in runtime. ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9fd3c959-d4aa-45dd-b09e-3817a7bbfeae) --- To run this PR locally, use the following command: ``` docker run -it --rm -p 3000:3000 -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock --add-host host.docker.internal:host-gateway -e SANDBOX_RUNTIME_CONTAINER_IMAGE=docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/runtime:07b0f7a-nikolaik --name openhands-app-07b0f7a docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/openhands:07b0f7a ```

issues.title: perf(condensation) Condenser that uses cache from agent - Prompt like LLMSummaryCondenser
issues.body:
This was an experiment that branched off from https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/pull/7588

Instead of trying to come up with a new type of condensation-prompt that uses message-index, I use the exact same prompt as LLMSummaryCondenser.

- [ ] This change is worth documenting at https://docs.all-hands.dev/ 
- [ ] Include this change in the Release Notes. If checked, you **must** provide an **end-user friendly** description for your change below

**End-user friendly description of the problem this fixes or functionality that this introduces.**

Greatly reduces the cost of doing a condensation by using the cache of the llm

---

# LLM Context Condensation and Cache

## Context

I have started to be able to get stuff done with OpenHands + Claude 3.7. But one thing that keeps happening, is 
that as soon as the conversation gets longer, 
* I run into the rate-limit. This slows me down, obviously.
* I spend a lot of money on tokens. 

But what really hits me, is when a LLM condensation happens. 

## Cache enables long conversations

### Cost of Using Cache with Anthropic API

According to [Anthropic's pricing](https://www.anthropic.com/pricing#anthropic-api):

- **Prompt caching write**: $3.75 / MTok  (just input is $3 / MTok but I will treat them as the same here. )
- **Prompt caching read**: $0.30 / MTok  
- **Output**: $15 / MTok  

This means that cached input tokens cost one-tenth as much as fresh input tokens.

### Example

Imagine we start with a 10k token initial prompt. 
Then we have a 5 follow up prompts, that add 1000 input tokens each. 

#### Legend:

```
+   1k input cache write ~0.3Cent
-   1k output ~1.5 Cent
#   1k input cache read ~0.03Cent
```

A regular conversation might go like this
```
+++-  initial prompt and response
####+- follow up
######+- regular response
########+- regular response
##########++++- big response
###############+- follow up
#################+- follow up
###################+- follow up
```

10 * `+` * 0.3  = 3 Cent

79 * `#` * 0.03 = 2.3 Cent

8 *  `-` * 1.5 = 12 Cent

Total:  17.3 Cent

Imagine we did not have caching

(89 `#` or `+`) * 0.3 = 26.7 Cent

8 *  `-` * 1.5 = 12 Cent

Total:  38.7 Cent

That's more than twice the price. So in this example caching really brings a benefit. This also matches my real life experience. 

## Current condensation does not use cache

Our current condensation method creates a completely new prompt, which does not take advantage of caching.

Continuing the example from above

```
+++-  initial prompt and response
####+- follow up
######+- regular response
########+- regular response
##########++++- big response
###############+- follow up
#################+- follow up
###################+- follow up
+++++++++++++++++++++-- condensation
###++-  conversation continues
```

Here a condensation reduces the context window from 21k down to 5k(of which 3k are the initial prompt).

But we pay a lot for it.

### Cost of Condensation

For the condensation operation:

21 * `+` * 0.3  = 6.3 Cent

2 *  `-` * 1.5 = 3 Cent

Total: 9.3 Cent

That is because we essentially now pay for every input token twice, when we could have just paid for the cache version instead(at 10% the cost. )

## Condenser uses cache

We could greatly reduce the amount of new input tokens of the condensation if we could use the cache of the conversation. 
This can be easily achieved by 
* using the **exact** same prompt as before, except
* with the condensation prompt added as the last message.

That way we will only pay full for the condensation prompt, which is just about 1k right now. Everything else should be cached. 

```
+++-  
####+- 
######+-
########+- 
##########++++- 
###############+- 
#################+-
###################+- 
#####################+-- condensation cached with prompt last
###++-  conversation continues
```
1 * `+` * 0.3  = 0.3 Cent

21 * `#` * 0.03 = 0.63 Cent

2 *  `-` * 1.5 = 3 Cent

Total: 3.93 Cent

That is less than half of the price without cache(9.3 Cent).

# Implementation

## Change existing interfaces

The signature of the method `Condenser.condense` was changed to     

`def condense(self, view: View, state: State, agent=None) -> View | Condensation:
`

https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/pull/7893/commits/797acd021e992aff384dc560d2ecb1fa6973821e


That way the agent can pass himself to the condenser. This is necessary, because the condenser must know the agent to build the prompt the same way. 

The CodeActAgent implements the new interface `LLMCompletionProvider`, which abstracts how any particular agent builds its prompt.

https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/pull/7893/commits/6b8cd2025d3f5b7ff3dfb70a2ea0794612c24f7c


# Condensation with Cache

https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/pull/7893/commits/8cde944f1a44a025238199babcbf6f514fa35604


## CachingCondenser

[CachingCondenser](https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/pull/7893/commits/8cde944f1a44a025238199babcbf6f514fa35604#diff-84689ca73519929adaf60559b5d6225634e484a4e68b840ed031365b77159114) is a base class that appends the prompt(generated by the subclass) to the messages of the agent. 

```
        # Convert events to messages using the agent's method
        base_messages = agent._get_messages(events)

        # Use the agent's method to build the parameters
        # This ensures that the parameters are consistent with the agent's LLM
        params = agent.build_llm_completion_params(events, state)
        # Now we add our own prompt at the end
        params['messages'] += agent.llm.format_messages_for_llm(
            [self.createCondensationPrompt(events, state, base_messages)]
        )

        # Get the LLM response
        response = agent.llm.completion(**params)
```

## LLMAgentCacheCondenser

Is the actual condenser class. It creates the prompt that controls the condensation. The prompt was taken from LLMSummaryCondenser. 

It also controls when the condenser is activated(like all other condensers). 
It also supports triggering a condensation by user keyword ("CONDENSE!"), which I used during testing and kept, because I liked it. 

---
**Link of any specific issues this addresses.**
https://github.com/happyherp/OpenHands/issues/14

comments_data.body: @csmith49 Hey. Can you re-run your test with this? This should be just the same as LLMSummaryCondenser, except with cache-use.

# Test: Early Condensation by Keyword

## Setup 

Rev: 0c55c9acec8cd257bd75a563b0cca1520cdfd782

in `config.toml`:

```
[agent.codeactagent]
condenser = "LLMCacheAgentCondenser"
max-size = 50
```

Env:
```
DEBUG=1
```

Started as Web-Application from VSCode

## Test

* Start new conversation "Hi."
* Agent answers greeting
* User: "CONDENSE!"
* Agent responds kind of awkward to the hidden(to the user) condensation summary

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ab5764d8-5585-4159-a9f9-f9df5ab95d06)

## Result
from the trajectory: [trajectory-a8c2c67ffb48427f9e31602f30e22fc3.json](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19867085/trajectory-a8c2c67ffb48427f9e31602f30e22fc3.json)

### Agent Greeting
This is the last llm-call before the condensation

```json
  {
    "id": 7,

Okay, I've got the data in.

## Setup

I'm specifically comparing this condenser to the runs reported in the blog post here. That means a few options are standardized, and _may_ not be optimal for actual usage.

I'm comparing this **Cache** strategy to the **Baseline** and **Condenser** strategies, using the same configuration in [this blog post](https://www.all-hands.dev/blog/openhands-context-condensensation-for-more-efficient-ai-agents).

Specifically, I'm setting `keep_first=4` and `max_size=80` for the condensers, and running on a randomly-selected (but consistent across the strategies) set of 50 SWE-Bench Verified instances with 150 max iterations.

This subset correlates well with performance on the full data set, and generates trajectories with a good spread of lengths. Reported results are averaged over three runs on this subset.

## The Results

Some summary results first:

strategy | resolved | avg. cost | avg. iteration | avg. cost-per-iter.
---|---|---|---|---
baseline | 52.7% | $1.22 | 49.5 | $0.025
cache | 47.3% | $4.04 | 56.6 | $0.071
condenser | 54.0% | $1.21 | 55.8 | $0.022

The caching strategy hits the resolution rate pretty hard, and seems to dramatically increase the average cost-per-iteration while doing so. If we break out the average cost vs. iteration we start to see what's happening:

![visualization](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fdf8c519-b664-4ef1-a4e4-057ec0f31ff7)

There's big spikes in cost that correspond to the condensation phases. If we break out the different token usages:

![asdf](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5515bfdd-4fc2-4bd9-876c-766a1fb523cf)

Then we see the cost comes from the fact that after condensation there aren't any cache reads and we have way too many cache writes. **I'm guessing the evaluation entry-point I used isn't setting up the agent correctly**. I used [this script](https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/blob/0b728c0c7981c43ab09a5d73e20db5765f3d28a9/evaluation/benchmarks/swe_bench/run_infer.py) and modified [the metadata](https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/blob/0b728c0c7981c43ab09a5d73e20db5765f3d28a9/evaluation/benchmarks/swe_bench/run_infer.py#L789-L797) to include the condenser config.

## Conclusions

Whoops.

Still, these runs tell us a few things. They tell us the condensation strategy is impacting the resolution rate -- just looking at the token consumption per iteration shows a pretty big difference in how often and how aggressively the condensation is happening between the **Cache** and **Condenser** strategies.

For future tests I'll want to minimize the number of differences between the two strategies to _just_ highlight how changing the summary generation impacts cost and performance. That probably means tweaking the **Condenser** strategy to forget just as aggressively and/or the **Cache** strategy to be less aggressive.

The runs also give us a clue as to what the performance cost _could_ be were things configured correctly on my end. I went through and swapped the cache reads and writes post-condensation for the **Cache** strategy -- this still isn't quite fair to **Cache**, but it brings the average cost-per-iteration down to $0.027, which is much closer to being competitive.

## Take-Aways

I'm glad to run more experiments if y'all think it would be fruitful. I'm a little concerned about the performance gap, but maybe with some tweaks to the prompt or the amount of forgotten events that can be closed without impacting cost _too_ much?

Also a little concerned with needing extra configuration steps to get working (we've got something like 4 different configuration pipelines). Outside the scope of the current exploration, for sure, but something we'll need to resolve at some point.

I just saw we currently don't use that anymore. When we used it: the reminder phrase contained a variable, which was incremented every step. That cannot be part of the cached prompt, because if it was, it would write the cache, and never hit it. So it needs added in a different TextContent after the TextContent with the cache marker.
> If there's something in the cache-marked TextContent that changes, that could explain it too. 🤔
> 
> image
> It's interesting that this thing, whatever it is, seems to only kick into action after the first condensation, not before it, if I interpret this correctly.

Yes. Some weird stuff going on after the first condensation that effectively disables caching. But on top of that, the resolution rate **also** goes down. 

The good thing is, the cache write during condensation is gone.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cf6bb19d-0b07-4d36-ac49-e922b5d3a199)

@csmith49 can you provide the trajectory or other output of a single iteration where it does badly, so I can take a look at it? Maybe it's something obvious. 

>  I'm guessing the evaluation entry-point I used isn't setting up the agent correctly

Yeah, that could explain things 😅

It would be best If I could run swe-bench myself. 

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c0c0506f-77f4-4cf9-957d-bc6a25fcc422)

Which in my case involves buying a new hard-drive.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/62b07ec2-4353-408e-ac8e-c14ef2aad022)

Actually, it also involves someone else buying the hard-drive, downloading swe-bench on it, and then mailing it to me.

ok. Its not **that** bad. 

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/83f1548f-3d85-4c2b-a5fb-0a682a8ea89b)

But still. 4 days.

@happyherp I've got the trajectories for all three runs loaded up here: https://github.com/csmith49/oh-trajectories

> Yes. Some weird stuff going on after the first condensation that effectively disables caching. But on top of that, the resolution rate also goes down.

If you've seen non SWE-bench runs with the appropriate caching behavior, I'm fine chalking this up to my configuration mistake for now. Maybe the completion logs can reveal more?

The resolution rate is a bit harder to explain. My gut says there's too much context being summarized and it's hurting their quality, but I haven't looked through the trajectories to see yet.

> The good thing is, the cache write during condensation is gone.

That's also gone for the current condenser (thanks to #7781), but the runs I'm showing you were before that was merged.

@happyherp I ran 2 instances just so we can look at them, attached: 
[claude-3-7-sonnet-run1.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19978607/claude-3-7-sonnet-run1.zip)

Command:
`...EVAL_DOCKER_IMAGE_PREFIX="us-central1-docker.pkg.dev/evaluation-092424/swe-bench-images" \./evaluation/benchmarks/swe_bench/scripts/run_infer.sh llm.claude-ah HEAD CodeActAgent 2 100 2 "princeton-nlp/SWE-bench_Verified" test condenser.default_4_20`

config.toml:
```
[condenser.default_4_20]
type="agentcache"
keep_first=4
max_size=20
```

Branch:
this branch + https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/commit/2a041e70a4288cecbc217db83c1043134665c0ff

Please note that this has only inference results, one ended exceeding max iterations

Ah, thank you Calvin! That's awesome, the `llm_completions` folder in particular, is great to see what actually happened.

On a side note, I picked up the way I configured the condenser for eval runs in a PR here:
- https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/pull/8177

Hopefully makes it a little easier to configure and run.

issues.title: Fix Issue #2121: Implement GLOBAL_MAX_ITERATIONS Configuration to Limit Total Task Iterations
issues.body:
In this update, I introduced the `GLOBAL_MAX_ITERATIONS` configuration across various parts of the OpenDevin framework to control the total number of steps an agent can take to complete a task. 

Changes include modifying the evaluation scripts (`run_infer.py) for mint, humanevalfix, gaia, and EDA `to integrate this new configuration, enhance logging, improve task filtering, and ensure proper iteration handling. 

The `SimplifiedEnv` class in `env.py` for mint was updated to implement global iteration limits and add detailed logging. The `Tutorial.md` was revised to include the new configuration and improved explanations for handling iterations and sandbox setups. 

The UML diagram (`backend_architecture.puml`) was updated to reflect the new architecture. The `CodeActAgent` in `codeact_agent.py` was enhanced with global iteration handling, iteration reminders, and improved logging. 

Lastly, the prompt handling in `prompt.py` for the browsing agent was updated to include `GLOBAL_MAX_ITERATIONS` in flags, enhancing main prompt handling, and improving history and observation prompts. These changes ensure that agents adhere to a global limit on iterations, preventing excessive API calls and resource usage, and improving the maintainability, functionality, and debugging capabilities across.

Side Note: I was wondering if `GLOBAL_MAX_ITERATIONS` should be tracked in a central, thread-safe manner, potentially using a class that manages these counts and limits.
The state object, which tracks the overall status and iterations, should be accessible globally to ensure that both the parent and child agents respect the global iteration limit.

Like refactoring the code to centralize the handling of iteration limits, which involves creating a class (possibly named RateLimiter or similar) that encapsulates the logic for managing iteration counts and limits.
Where all references to MAX_ITERATIONS should be updated to use this new class, ensuring that all parts of the system consistently enforce the iteration limits.

issues.title: [Refactor, Fix]: Agent controller state/metrics management
issues.body:
- [ ] This change is worth documenting at https://docs.all-hands.dev/
- [x] Include this change in the Release Notes. If checked, you **must** provide an **end-user friendly** description for your change below

**End-user friendly description of the problem this fixes or functionality this introduces.**

- Make tracking for metrics more accurate and fault tolerant (accumulated cost, token usage, etc)
- Does not track metrics in a centralized manner yet (metrics reported in FE are for the main agent, and do not include metrics for auto generate convo titles, or running the condenser)

#### Problems

We have many problems with the way we handle budget caps in the agent controller

1. The budget information is reset when the user decides to continue after hitting the convo budget cap
2. We store accumulated cost in both the agent state and llm state, and they have eventual consistency
3. We extended budget when the traffic control state is `PAUSED`; but nowhere in the agent controller do we set it that way, and thus I'm unable to extend budget even if I wanted to
4. Throttle logic and iteration extension logic seem to be scattered across different parts of the agent controlled
5. When budget is extended, we simply extend the current max by the initial amount; we should use the current accumulated cost as the new starting point
6. When the agent is delegated, the initial amount is initialized as the max_budget setting. This means that the delegate extends the budget by twice the normal amount the parent would


#### Fixes

This PR we do the following

1. Removing any resetting of accumulated costs
2. Extend the budget when we are throttled, and remove the unnecessary complexity of `PAUSED` state for traffic control
3. Organize throttling and max cap extensions in one place (when the agent goes from error to running)
4. We extend the agent budget based on the current accumulated cost and the initial delta amount
5. We track delta amounts for budget now. This means if the agent or the parent hits the budget cap, we extend by a fixed delta amount (fixes delegate from extending budget cap in multiples, see [comment](https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/pull/8764#issuecomment-2919777095))
6. Controller state always holds the most current budget cap and accumulate cost, simplifying tracking

This helps us establish the following assumptions going forward

1. Accumulated cost is never reset, we're always looking at the current cost for the conversation even after extending budget
2. When restarting a conversation, we will resume with the same accumulated cost and budget caps from when we last left off
3. The metrics for the controller state and llm metrics are always the same. Metrics are always accumulated over time, we never start a fresh copy. Instead, for delegate agents we'll create a snapshot of the parent's metrics. The different between child and parent metrics gives us the local metrics for the delegate (this also fixes the problem where the controller metrics had eventual consistency with global llm metrics)


Fixes #8858
Fixes #8238

---

To run this PR locally, use the following command:
```
docker run -it --rm   -p 3000:3000   -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock   --add-host host.docker.internal:host-gateway   -e SANDBOX_RUNTIME_CONTAINER_IMAGE=docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/runtime:922b0a6-nikolaik   --name openhands-app-922b0a6   docker.all-hands.dev/all-hands-ai/openhands:922b0a6
```

comments_data.body:
Thank you for taking this up! It can be a headache ❤️

Related, please take a look
- https://github.com/All-Hands-AI/OpenHands/issues/8111

Re: `StateManager`
The first attempt at a split in the comments in the issue above, as Carlos pointed out, feels like it splits a god object into multiple mini-gods. 😅 Still easier to read than a 1,4k file, but idk. IMHO a 'state manager' moves code, but I'm not fully sure it reduces complexity? 🤔 

State is the state of the system, multiple things read it to adapt.

What if (unbaked thought) we think of it this way
- budget and iterations are ControlFlags. We have a state machine kind of logic, for how each of them influences the controller. Could they be small dataclasses that each know how to `check()` - true or false; `expand()` when needed; maybe even return the correct enum `next()`, considering headless/non-headless? So they're probably initialized with `state`...
- history is different, I agree we could be better off with it taken out of the agent_controller, but it... doesn't control the app/controller behavior.
- nit: could we avoid the word 'manager' or 'handler' in the class names, and still express what we want to express? They're so generic, everything can "manage stuff". Sometimes the answer is no, ok, just nitpick: it may be worth to ask the question.
Thanks that's great feedback! Let me see what I can do about this

Okay I took a shot at control flags for budget and iteration constraints 

It did end up simplifying things since limit checks, limit states, and limit extensions are handled within the dataclass

I think this is a good stopping point

1. we have fixed metrics management
2. since `AgentController` is a god object, we've introduced control flags and moved history management out of the controller

I'm afraid attempting to further simplify the agent controller from this point is out of scope for this PR
@enyst would like that I hold off from merging util you've had more time to look into this?
I think we’re better off merging, we need this. Thank you!
Thanks for the help with reviews! I did one last QA and it went well, will be merging
